summary: This is an FBI 302 form documenting an interview with a Bureau of Prisons employee who was in charge of cameras at the Metropolitan Correctional Center (MCC). The employee details the outdated and malfunctioning camera system at MCC, including specific failures around the time of Jeffrey Epstein's death on August 10, 2019, and describes being present during the resuscitation attempt and subsequent efforts to recover video.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: The inmate at MCC whose death on August 10, 2019, is the subject of the camera system inquiry. The interviewee was one of the personnel who briefly tried to resuscitate him.

events.title: DVR 2 System Failure at MCC
events.description: A system failure occurred on DVR 2 of the camera recording system at the Metropolitan Correctional Center.

events.title: DVR 2 Motherboard Failure
events.description: The motherboard on DVR 2 of the MCC camera system failed.

events.title: Hard Drive Failure and Epstein Death
events.description: A hard drive failure occurred on the MCC camera system. A body alarm sounded around 6:00 AM, and personnel, including the interviewee, responded and attempted to resuscitate Jeffrey Epstein.

events.title: Interview of BOP Employee
events.description: A Bureau of Prisons employee was interviewed by an Assistant United States Attorney, a Task Force Officer Detective, and an FBI Special Agent regarding the MCC camera system and the events of August 10, 2019.

locations: United States Attorneys Office (USAO), Southern District of New York (SDNY), New York, New York
keyFacts: The camera system at the Metropolitan Correctional Center was over 20 years old, analog, poorly maintained, and frequently malfunctioned.
At the time of Jeffrey Epstein's death on August 10, 2019, only one hard drive of the camera system was working, and a hard drive failure occurred that day.
Replacing the failed hard drives would have wiped all prior recorded data from the system.
An FBI agent was reportedly the one who physically removed the DVR unit containing the failed hard drives after the incident.
The interviewee, a BOP employee, was present during the response to Epstein's cell and participated in the attempted resuscitation.
